generated_text: The structure of hydrate is of great interest in the fields of geophysics, geology, and oceanography. The structure of hydrate is also important for the understanding of the physical properties of the hydrate system, such as the hydrate stability zone, the hydrate-bearing capacity of sediments, and the mechanical properties of hydrate-bearing sediments. In this work, we report the structure of hydrate formed by neon hydrate, which is a new hydrate formed by a noble gas. This work provides a new perspective for the study of the structure of hydrate.

The foundations of quantum mechanics are a subject of intense debate. The most promising approach, initiated by von Neumann, is to reconstruct quantum mechanics from a few basic axioms. The most important of these axioms is that the set of density operators forms a convex set. This axiom is controversial, and there are several different ways to formulate it. We show that the controversy is due to different choices of mathematical language. We provide axioms for a category that is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces, and show that the set of density operators is a convex set in this category.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of vertebrate hosts. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme, and show that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results provide insights into the molecular basis of the extreme reduction in gene content and function that is characteristic of the Myxozoa. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to antagonize the antiviral immune response is a major obstacle to the development of effective antiviral therapies. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, is able to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN by hijacking the nuclear import pathway. Our results reveal a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings have important implications for the development of effective antiviral therapies against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of this inhibition is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 70%. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decrease as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, and that the variability of yields will increase. Here, we quantify the magnitude of these changes in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty, underscores the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, we still do not know how diverse LMH assemblages coexist. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap at a species level, and that this approach can be used to reveal that LMH partition food resources in ways that are not easily predicted from body size alone. These results suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized, and that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of LMH in the functioning of African savanna ecosystems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the U.S. economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses between March 28 and April 4, 2020, to understand the impact of the pandemic on small businesses. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile, and many have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, many small businesses are also planning to apply for the new federal loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly because of the selective removal of small particles by food webs and ballasting processes. This study is of fundamental importance to understand the nature and the significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are important for the understanding of the origin of the elements and the history of the solar system. We determined the ages of 40 interstellar grains from the Murchison meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We show that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We also show that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system was not yet formed when the grains condensed.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 5. This has led to a decrease in the effective catch per unit of effort, which is a measure of the pressure exerted on the ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all organisms. In this study, we show that the ability to reproduce is also a trait that can be manipulated and that the manipulation of this trait can have important consequences for the evolution of the species.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in the brain in response to inflammation, is also able to cleave the C terminus of α-syn, leading to its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. Finally, we show that VX-765 is able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA and other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. To control each function, the endothelium receives information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network that is effective in both local and global communication. The network is also designed to be highly dynamic and robust. These findings provide a new perspective on the design of the endothelium and its communication network. They also provide a new understanding of the mechanisms that control the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has presented enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the data sources and signals that we have developed to address these challenges, and provide examples demonstrating that the data are useful for tracking the pandemic, augmenting traditional public health reporting, and empowering research and decision-making. The data are available through an open API, and the code used to generate the figures in this paper is available for download. We hope that the data and code will be useful to others in tracking the pandemic and in their research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular basis of the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. The role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome is not well understood, but they are likely important in the regulation of the gut microbiome. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is still poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of developing subordinate status, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identifies an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover multifunctional structures with optimal material compositions and distributions that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It can also be extended to design multifunctional structures with complex and navigable responses. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we show that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is involved in the heterochronous regulation of the human genome, is also involved in the regulation of the hemoglobin system. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 overexpression in erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern, resulting in a more fetal-like pattern. This study provides a mechanism for the chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. (Show more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is associated with the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the resistance of cancer cells to ferroptosis. Finally, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer with PI3K-AKT pathway mutation. These findings provide a rationale for the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction as a new strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the most important risk factor for heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. This is partly due to the fact that older forests are declining, and the NWFP has not yet been able to halt this decline. We also show that the NWFP has not been effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our results highlight the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral forests does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. The design strategy presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics against a broad range of pathogens.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we propose a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on dilated convolutions, which are able to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the impact of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we show that the evolution of this iconic group of fish is linked to the hydroclimate of the region. We show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the hydroclimate of the region. We also show that the evolution of the species flock is linked to the hydroclimate of the region.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime suppresses melatonin, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, all of which have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the history of the Earth, but the cause of this cooling is still debated. One of the most popular hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. However, the evidence for such impacts is not conclusive. We show that the osmium isotope composition of sediments and magnetic grains from the Younger Dryas boundary (YDB) sites in the United States and Belgium is consistent with terrestrial sources, and the spherules from the YDB in Pennsylvania are consistent with their source being from a meteorite impact. These results provide evidence for a bolide impact at the YDB. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been a matter of debate. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is complex and depends on the type of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, and to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. Beetle diversity thus appears to have resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding PCWDEs. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the size of the population was related to the amount of variation in plane performance, which may have overwhelmed participants’ working memory and weakened their ability to selectively copy the best-adapted plane(s). Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. This study has implications for the study of CCE in general.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE is a lipid-binding protein that is expressed in many cell types in the central nervous system (CNS). Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in the hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with a higher rate of neurodegeneration in AD patients.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere that is 1220 km in diameter and has a density of 11.0–11.9 g/cm3. It is the densest solid in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of molten iron, but the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is metastable at core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also provides an explanation for the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. They also have implications for the origin of other dense solids in the solar system. View Full-Text

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are not well understood, the drug is known to increase the activity of the brain’s reward system, the striatum. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to the stimulation of the striatum is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for language comprehension are among the most studied topics in neuroscience. However, the brain’s computation of language is not understood, in part because of the difficulty of measuring the brain’s activity during naturalistic language comprehension. Here, we show that a popular class of artificial neural networks, which have been shown to be highly predictive, can be used to understand the brain’s neural responses to language in the fMRI scanner. These models are not only predictive of the brain’s activity, but also of how well participants understand the language presented to them. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain’s language comprehension mechanism. They also suggest that artificial neural networks may be a powerful tool for understanding the brain’s language comprehension mechanism.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful paradigm in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of machine learning, but rather a property of a specific class of problems. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a neural network. This result has implications for the future of machine learning, as well as for scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the last 10 y. It shows that the study’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and that the study’s conclusion was not questioned. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two distinct bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a non-nerve-damaging disease known as lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably conserved, and that they are still able to cause disease. This study provides a unique insight into the evolution of leprosy, and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main resources for the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the relation between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems is captured by a quasiparticle picture, which is exact in the scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we show that it is valid for a wide class of integrable models. We also show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement. This result is a milestone in the study of the relation between thermodynamics and entanglement.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available for use in humans is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a vaccine candidate that is easy to manufacture, can be administered in a single dose, and is highly protective against COVID-19.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of neuroscience and a key topic in the history of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is more complex and requires a different approach. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the power of animal cognition. We also show that the evolution of brain neurons is the key factor that determines the power of animal cognition.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is controlled by a small number of key proteins. This study shows that one of these proteins, TRAP1, is a key regulator of the cell cycle and of metabolism.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. ADF is also involved in the development of cancer. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is still poorly understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks, which is essential for many cellular processes. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF in a variety of cellular processes and cancer. They also provide a general principle for understanding the action of other mechanochemical enzymes in cells. This principle may be useful for the design of new drugs and therapies.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation of reward-related regions and greater hunger and desire for food, leading to a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. The findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its associated health consequences. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we show that the island was settled by multiple waves of migration, with a recent contribution from Southeast Asia. We also show that the settlement history is not only driven by the arrival of humans, but also by the history of Madagascar itself.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for the study of emotional contagion in the real world. They also suggest that, contrary to popular belief, people are not always aware of the emotions they are experiencing.

Messenger RNA sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have a profound impact on the translation of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA sequences can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA sequences can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA sequences can have a modest impact on the translation of the mRNA. This study provides a deeper understanding of the impact of messenger RNA modifications on the translation of the mRNA. (Show more)

This study shows that a sense that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

Aquatic mammals are larger than their terrestrial relatives, but the extent to which this size increase is due to ecological, biomechanical, or physiological factors remains unclear. We use a model of the energetic constraints imposed by the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal lineages toward a common body size attractor. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment and is not due to the release of size constraints.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically costly diseases in the world. Rhinoviruses are the major cause of the common cold, and the development of rhinovirus vaccines is a major goal in the field of vaccine research. However, the mechanisms that control rhinovirus replication are not fully understood. In this study, we show that rhinovirus replication is more efficient at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the cool temperature promotes a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells, which partially accounts for the increased rhinovirus replication at cool temperature. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may lead to the development of new strategies to control rhinovirus replication. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major human pathogen that causes a variety of infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and urinary tract infections. The ability of this opportunistic pathogen to cause disease is due to its ability to adapt to its environment and to produce a wide range of virulence factors. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the pili, which is required for the regulation of a variety of virulence factors. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how type IV pili are used by bacteria to sense their environment and highlights the importance of this sensing mechanism for the pathogenicity of this important human pathogen. This work also provides a new perspective on the evolution of mechanosensitive signaling systems in bacteria.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and the use of newer-generation insecticides has increased even more. However, the impact of these pesticides on the quality of surface water is still poorly understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the animal world has not been immune. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, which is a significant finding because deer are a major source of human exposure to the virus. We also show that the virus has the potential to spread between deer populations. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems that they cause, and the solutions that are needed. We also propose a new approach to hydropower that can be used to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is considered the primary pathogenic factor. However, the role of the immune system in AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type affected in AD, are able to produce a variety of immune factors, even in the absence of extracellular Aβ deposits. We demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. These findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. View Full-Text

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. The domestication of the chicken is a matter of debate, but the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens comes from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Maresha site is the earliest known site where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken and its spread across the Mediterranean basin. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a key process in biology, and it is of great interest to understand the details of the folding pathway. Here we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of the large maltose binding protein. We show that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, and we identify the steps in the folding of the protein. The results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA molecules. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, prefers to remove the monophosphorylated RNA as a prelude to rapid degradation. This is the first example of a decapping enzyme that prefers to remove the monophosphorylated RNA as a prelude to degradation. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of the enzyme positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of immune dysfunction is the expansion of immunosuppressive cells, such as myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. In this study, we demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore the immune system function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The results of this study may also lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of other immune-related diseases.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly marine. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a reference for future studies on the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, in which a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change is proportional to the energy density. The simplest model of SOC is the sandpile model, which is a discrete model. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, it is brittle and has a low fracture toughness. Therefore, it is important to understand the effect of strain on its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly without phonon instability. This finding is important for understanding the effect of strain on the electronic and phonon structures of diamond, which will help in the development of diamond-based devices.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic, and that the female reproductive tract makes substantial contributions to the sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting the formation of a platelet plug. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding kinetics, providing a mechanism for the observed gain of function. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD, and it may be relevant to other diseases in which VWF is involved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the last decade. However, the role of viruses in human health has been much less studied, and the human virome is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which we use to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We also provide a resource for the community to use in the study of the human virome. This database will be useful for the study of the human virome, and will be a valuable resource for the study of the human microbiome.

This is due to the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe aerosols and clouds simultaneously. The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the early Earth has been estimated using a variety of methods, but the results have been inconsistent. We used the thermostability of ancestral enzymes to estimate the temperature of the surface environment of ancient organisms. Our results suggest that the temperature of the early Earth decreased over time. This finding is consistent with other methods of estimating the temperature of the early Earth and provides a new method for estimating the temperature of the early Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their structure and function. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel that is normally open and inactivated by slow C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-inactivation is state-dependent, and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), the host cell in which it replicates. Here, we show that one of these mechanisms is the binding of a parasite protein to a receptor on the RBC surface. We show that this binding leads to a change in the physical properties of the RBC, which is required for invasion. This finding has implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs, as it suggests that the physical properties of the RBC are a critical target for drug action. It also has implications for the development of new strategies to prevent malaria, as it suggests that the physical properties of the RBC could be targeted to reduce the risk of infection. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are still not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and the bandgap can be tuned continuously. This work provides a new route to tailor the electronic properties of diamond, which will be useful for applications in the future.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of humidity on viral transmission has been well-established, the impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the formation of syntactic structures is consistent with a tree-like structure, but that the brain also uses this information to merge words into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to compress syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This suggests that the brain may use a tree-like structure to represent the structure of language, but that it also uses this information to build more compact representations of the language stream.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. This differential regulation may be important in tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are incompletely understood. Here we report the identification of a brain circuit that promotes overeating. This circuit is located in the lateral hypothalamus, and it is activated by electrical or optogenetic stimulation of neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area. This circuit is also activated by stimulation of a second brain region, the substantia nigra, but not the ventral tegmental area. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in normal feeding. However, it may contribute to the development of obesity.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both partners, but they are also a major source of crop losses. One of the main challenges in agriculture is to develop sustainable strategies to improve the efficiency of these associations. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of bacterial gene expression in a symbiosis. This synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis could be used to develop a sustainable strategy to deliver nitrogen in agriculture.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their bodies to sense the world around them, but some animals, such as spiders, can sense the world without a body. This study shows that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can sense the sound of an approaching prey or predator without a body. The spider uses the threads of its web as an acoustic antenna to detect the sound of an approaching prey or predator. The spider can also adjust the size of the acoustic antenna to suit its needs. This study provides a unique model for studying the sensing of sound without a body. It also provides a unique model for studying the sensing of sound without a body.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This protein can be used to generate a VLP vaccine, which can be produced at a high titer and is expected to be cost-effective.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of the neural crest, a group of cells that gives rise to a variety of tissues and organs. In the last years, mutations in the kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) were identified in a significant number of neuroblastoma patients. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrALK, is activated by the zebrafish homolog of ALKALs, DrALKals. We also show that DrALKals are involved in the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived cells. Our results provide evidence for a role of ALK/ALKals in neural crest development and suggest that ALKALs may be promising targets for neuroblastoma therapy.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex story that has been difficult to reconstruct. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during the formative years of its emergence. Our results suggest that the pathogen was not a direct descendant of Yersinia pseudotuberculosis, as previously thought, and that it was likely adapted to the flea vector. We also find evidence of a single lineage of plague that persisted for thousands of years without significant diversification, and the presence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide a more nuanced understanding of the origins of plague and its early evolution. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. The agricultural management of grasslands and cropland has been shown to have a large impact on the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of different agricultural management practices on soil organic carbon (SOC) storage in the United States are still highly uncertain. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil. These practices can increase the amount of SOC stored in the more stable mineral-associated organic matter pool, which is the most important pool for long-term SOC storage. These results highlight the potential of grasslands and livestock integration to mitigate climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was validated by the fact that the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a chemical basis for the red color of nectar, which is of interest to the scientific community and the general public.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations and the end of the last ice age is still largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the individuals was heterogeneous, and that some of them had a genetic background that is not commonly associated with Europe. In addition, we found that many variants that are associated with positive selection in modern Europeans were already present in the population at the time of the study. These findings provide new insights into the history of Europe and the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of the continent. (Less)

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the origins of bat coronaviruses and their potential to cause human infections. Here, we report that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, are different from those of the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus. These results suggest that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the origins of bat coronaviruses and their potential to cause human infections. They also suggest that bat coronaviruses, which are genetically related to MERS-CoV, may pose a threat to human health. View Full-Text

This study provides a detailed description of the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. We show that mNGS can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study provides a blueprint for mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the synthesis of DNA lagging behind the replication fork. This process is known as DNA replication, and the lagging strand is synthesized in short fragments, known as Okazaki fragments. The synthesis of Okazaki fragments is catalyzed by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). In this study, we show that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is not as high as previously thought. This finding has important implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments, as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans. They also provide a rationale for the use of PCNA inhibitors in cancer therapy.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA. In vitro evolution of RNA molecules has led to the discovery of many important RNA structures, but the ability to synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origins of life and the evolution of RNA-based life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then connect these changes to economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of a neighborhood in determining its future physical appearance. This finding has implications for urban planning and redevelopment efforts.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the immune characteristics of the patients were identified. The results showed that the immune system was suppressed, and the inflammatory monocytes and T cells were activated, which may incite the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be a potential treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause damage to the cell. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is not. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC, which encodes a family of isocyanide natural products, binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of the ability to sense and respond to copper in fungi and the potential for the use of fungal natural products in biotechnology. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary environment is surprising. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is also surprising, as it is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of a sedimentary environment, silicic volcanism, and a sedimentary environment, all in the same location, is even more surprising.

Frost is one of the most important abiotic factors limiting plant growth and productivity in the Northern Hemisphere. The geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and this change is expected to be more pronounced in the future. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and this change is expected to be more pronounced in the future. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and this change is expected to be more pronounced in the future.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for the development of disease or are simply a consequence of the disease process. Here, we show that Th17 cells are required for the development of colitis, and that this requirement is dependent on the development of Th1-like cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are not simply a consequence of the disease process, but rather are required for the development of the disease. This finding has implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by a variety of genetic mutations, but the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS, which can be used to study the disease and identify potential therapies. This method will enable the study of the disease in a living patient model, and the identification of disease mechanisms and potential therapies. This will be of great benefit to ALS patients and their families.

The gut microbiota of ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. In this study, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which is a protein that is expressed by a variety of arthropods and is known to alter the permeability of the gut barrier. We also show that iafgp alters the composition of the gut microbiota, which is important for the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the gut microbiota of their vector, which is critical for the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages, and the study of their evolution is a central topic in avian paleontology. However, the study of the origins of the avian tail is complicated by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the group. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, which adds important information about the origins of the avian tail. Phylogenetic analysis recovers a clade uniting Jinguofortis and a previously enigmatic taxon, and this represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the Earth. This feedback is important because it is positive, meaning that increases in water vapor increase the water vapor, and so on. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This ability is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is linked to the presence of a specific group of proteins. We describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue-green colors in vertebrates. They also provide a new perspective on the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of pluripotency factor NANOG, and the stemness phenotype of breast cancer cells. This study provides a mechanism for the maintenance of cancer stem cells in hypoxic tumors, and may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term abortivum in Latin, used in many sources, has led some scholars to suggest that fetal skins were used, arguing that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins. Others have argued for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle underwent a major reorganization immediately preceding the extinction, and carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. These results will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD treatment. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two variants that are currently circulating in the United Kingdom and South Africa. We find that the variant with the D614G substitution has a more open conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. This may explain the higher transmissibility of this variant.

We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y

The study of the chemical properties of matter under pressure is of great interest for the understanding of the properties of matter at extreme conditions. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is of interest to chemists, physicists, and materials scientists.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including wildfires. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression are also difficult to quantify. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which, in turn, can reduce warming. This potentially reduces the rate of global warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. However, we also show that the effects of fire on climate are uncertain, and that the risk of more extreme fires is also possible. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the climate system and the need for a better understanding of the effects of climate change on fire regimes.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is one of the most studied in the animal–microbe world. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan, chitin, cyclically and in a precise time window, to the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the symbiotic organ. This glycan is required for the acidification of the organ, which is required for the symbiont to produce light. We propose that this is a general mechanism of control of symbiont populations in animal–microbe systems. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the timing of the light production in the symbiotic organ, and it may also have implications for the control of symbiont populations in other animal–microbe systems.
