Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which have led to the development of a sparse representation of an embedding space. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words, and we can also identify the gender bias of our topics. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We illustrate its application to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System.

The second plague pandemic, which started in the 14th century, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that this understanding is incomplete. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study challenges the current understanding of the history of the plague and its spread across Eurasia. It also provides a new perspective on the history of climate change in Europe. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem and are important for the evolution of life on Earth. However, they are also a source of economic loss due to the damage they cause to ships and infrastructure. Asteroids are also a source of genetic material for the pharmaceutical industry. In this study, we show that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic diversity is from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals, with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. View Full-Text

Bacteria are able to sense and respond to changes in their environment. One way they do this is by regulating the expression of genes. In Escherichia coli, small RNAs (sRNAs) are able to regulate the expression of other genes. We describe a small RNA that encodes a protein and shows that the protein interferes with the ability of another sRNA to regulate the expression of two other genes. This is an example of a mechanism that bacteria use to control the expression of genes that are important for survival.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of the agricultural community, and their knowledge is critical to monitor and manage agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the most comprehensive and long-running crop expert survey in the United States, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to monitor agricultural production and provide a new tool for the agricultural community.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major source of carbon dioxide (CO2) to the atmosphere and is expected to increase with climate warming. However, the magnitude of this increase is uncertain, as are the mechanisms driving it. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging evolutionary problems in biology, because it is difficult to study the process in its entirety. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy, is also a major evolutionary event in the history of plastids. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water resources in South Africa and elsewhere. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is important for water resource managers, policy makers, and the general public.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” has important implications for the history of science, the history of technology, and the history of human civilization.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The biosynthesis of the pigments that capture the energy of sunlight is a highly efficient and highly evolved process. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring, the most important reaction in the pathway, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and the identification of the proteins that are required for the reaction in oxygenic and alphaproteobacterial phototrophs. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the oxygenic photosynthesis pathway. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also a major feature of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of EAE, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of EAE. These findings suggest that ASK1 in astrocytes may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a new direction for the treatment of EAE and other neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism phenotype and may facilitate the identification of the causal paths. This information may be useful for the development of treatments for autism. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis, and mutations in the proteins that form the channel pore or the Ca2+ sensor that regulates channel activity result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 that result in a milder form of these conditions, and show that these mutations lead to constitutive activation of the CRAC channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The study of neurodegenerative diseases has been a major focus of neuroscience research for the past several decades. However, despite the tremendous advances in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of these diseases, there is no cure for any of them. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the mechanisms of spreading of protein aggregates in the nervous system. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the amino acid serine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to the unit, and have shown that it is a promising target for cancer therapy. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to therapy. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and may lead to the development of a new class of targeted cancer therapy.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a high mortality rate. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of genes, including those encoding the proteins superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are caused by a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the properties of the atoms, and the atoms can be used to control the properties of the photonic crystals. This is a new way to control the properties of matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is a major topic in plant science. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a reconsideration of the origin of the flowering plants. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is an important plant for the study of the origin of the flowering plants because it is an early member of the Ceratophyllum clade, which is sister to the eudicots.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral genomes. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) genomes, which were recovered from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also show that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change, and its acceleration is a key indicator of the causes of that change. This study provides a consistent, high-quality time series of sea level acceleration, which is essential for understanding the causes of sea level change. The results are consistent with the conclusions of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) AR5, but the time series presented here are of higher quality and extend over a longer period.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to the elderly, but is seen in all adults born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In particular, the study of the transition states and transition-state-like species that are formed during the course of catalysis is a major focus of the field. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of a key transition-state-like species in a β-elimination reaction, providing a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the species and its role in the mechanism of the enzyme. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The disease has a high case fatality rate, and the emergence of new cases in 2018 stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a nucleotide analog that has been shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo, and to be effective against SARS-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provides a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

The symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is one of the most studied in the animal–microbe world. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan, chitin, cyclically and in a precise time window, to the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiont in the symbiotic organ. This glycan is required for the acidification of the organ, which is required for the symbiont to produce light. We propose that this is a general strategy used by animal hosts to control the activities of their symbionts.

This research has implications for the future of education. It shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and suspension rates reduced, through a simple, scalable intervention. This intervention is based on the idea that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This mindset is associated with better relationships and lower suspension rates. The intervention is scalable because it can be implemented by any teacher, in any school, and because it requires no additional resources. It is also effective, reducing suspension rates by half. This research has implications for the future of education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription. We found that the stalling of RNA polymerase II (pol II) is dependent on the regioisomeric structure of the alkylated DNA lesion. Furthermore, we found that the stalling of pol II is associated with the proofreading activity of TFIIS. The results from the present study provide mechanistic insights into the transcriptional lesion bypass routes and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This work also provides important mechanistic insights into the minor-groove sensing of pol II. Finally, this work provides a better understanding of the impact of DNA alkylation on transcription. This work will help to develop strategies to prevent the impact of DNA alkylation on transcription. This work will also help to develop strategies to prevent the impact of DNA alkylation on transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis, which is required for virus binding to cell receptors and for virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that the first cleavages of MERS S proteins compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages of MERS S proteins expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of global disease burden. The food choices people make are a key driver of the food system, and thus, a key lever for change. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This increase in vegetarian meals is sustained over time and is not offset by a decline in meat sales. These findings suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a significant impact on population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of six oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people around the world. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique structure that may contribute to the severity of the disease.

Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, and knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It arises in the context of big data and complex statistical models. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations that are found in the data, but only by searching for the strongest associations. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a better understanding of the strengths and limitations of these methods.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step for the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is still a major challenge. Transplantation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. In addition, the generation of ECs has become increasingly important for providing vascular plexus to regenerated organs, such as the liver. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone directly converts primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. The discovery of the oncogenic potential of the receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) has led to the identification of many potential ligands. However, the physiological ligands of these orphan RTKs have not been characterized. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of the mammalian ligands are essential for the development of the iridophores, which are a unique type of photoreceptor that is responsible for the coloration of the zebrafish. These experiments establish a physiological link between the ligands and the orphan RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are required for the differentiation of neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells into iridophores. This work provides a unique model to study the function of orphan RTKs and their ligands. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are still unclear, insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the interferon pathway, plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, leading to T2D. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are able to adapt to new hosts and to change their genome sequence, which is a major obstacle for the development of effective vaccines and antiviral drugs. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the virion, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence dependent and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that the packaging of the viral genome is a complex process, which is not only sequence dependent but also sequence independent. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. The role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and the development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been fully explored. In this study, we demonstrate that YAP/TAZ are activated by disturbed flow and play a critical role in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study may also provide a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then connect these changes to economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic outcomes of individuals and communities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic pesticide. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. View Full-Text

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, which allows for the characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the time to clearance of ZIKV in the plasma. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of the timing of treatment on the time to clearance of ZIKV in the plasma. These predictions can be used to guide the design of clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, providing a range of ecosystem services to millions of people worldwide. However, the widespread bleaching events observed in recent years are threatening the survival of many coral reefs. This study shows that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a direct consequence of the altered nutrient cycling that occurs during heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the body from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. Our results highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This study provides a deeper understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we show that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the expression of genes involved in the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which would have led to a reduction in Southern Ocean winds and a cooling of the climate. However, this explanation is highly improbable, and we show that a volcanic eruption, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion, is a more plausible explanation for the start of deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to be a milestone in the field of energy storage.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate after injury, and the reasons for this are unknown. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult nervous system. This discovery opens up a new avenue for the discovery of factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key determinant of the genetic diversity of a population. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that it is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The study of the brain’s functional architecture is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we show that the resting brain can be decomposed into a set of reproducible networks, which are functionally relevant in health and disease. This approach can be used to identify the brain’s functional architecture in healthy subjects and in patients with Parkinson’s disease, Alzheimer’s disease, and other neurodegenerative disorders. The results provide a new perspective on the organization of the human brain, which can be used to understand the functional consequences of disease and to develop new therapeutic strategies.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the most studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification of transfer RNAs. In this study, we show that a 5′ NAD+ modification is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This 5′ NAD+ cap appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and is found on pre-mRNAs and not on mature mRNAs. These results define a second 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the function of this modification in the cell. (Show more)

The study of epigenetic alterations in diabetes is a promising field of research, but the results are still controversial. We show that epigenetic alterations in DNA methylation persist in blood cells from people with diabetes for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), which is the most important study in the history of diabetes research. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia, and they are also associated with the metabolic memory observed in the long-term follow-up of the DCCT. These results support the idea that epigenetic alterations are involved in the mechanisms of metabolic memory. This study also provides a possible explanation for the differences in the results obtained in different studies. View Full-Text

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of effective treatment options has led to a high mortality rate. We show that the expression of a cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC patients. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells results in autophagy induction, AMPK activation, and inhibition of mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem, and the search for new therapeutic targets is needed. The gut microbiota has been shown to be involved in the development of psychiatric disorders, which suggests the existence of a gut–brain axis. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not well understood, and the contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the overall aroma of tomato fruit is still unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is involved in the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous compounds, which are not produced in other Solanaceae species. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity is a key driver of ecosystem functioning, and the loss of biodiversity is one of the most pressing threats to the functioning of Earth’s ecosystems. However, the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the impacts of global warming on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and highlights the need for a more holistic approach to the conservation of biodiversity. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional architecture is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for spatial navigation, are strongly coupled among themselves but have weaker links to other cell types. These results provide a detailed view of the functional architecture of MEC and may help to elucidate the neural basis of navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain. It is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, but the mechanisms underlying this loss are not fully understood. Here, we show that dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra are connected to other brain regions, including striosomes, which are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We also show that dopamine neurons are connected to striosomes in a unique way, forming specialized integrative units. These findings have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in Parkinson’s disease and may lead to new approaches for the treatment of the disease.

We all know it when we feel it, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the electrical signal that causes the heart to beat. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of the heart rate, which is the number of times the heart beats per minute. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are located in the wall of the right atrium. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and for the regulation of the heart rate. SAN cells are also responsible for the regulation of the heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure and other factors. SAN cells are important for the normal functioning of the heart.

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented. However, the role of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increased resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect was associated with an increase in silicon accumulation and enhanced jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and signaling. These results suggest that Si may promote insect herbivore resistance by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the interaction between silicon and jasmonate in plant defense, which may lead to the development of new strategies for insect pest control. The lipidome of macrophages is a key factor in the regulation of their functions. We show here that the activity of a specific enzyme, alkylglycerol monooxygenase, is a key regulator of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of a specific class of glycerophospholipids, which are important for the function of macrophages. The activity of this enzyme is modulated by the availability of tetrahydrobiopterin, which is a cofactor for the synthesis of the glycerophospholipids. This study reveals a new regulatory mechanism of the lipidome of macrophages and opens the way for further studies on the role of this enzyme in the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the integration of multiple features over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the ability of neurons to store information in their intrinsic properties. This is a departure from the traditional view that information is stored in the membrane potential. We show that the membrane potential is not necessary for memory, and that information can be stored in the dynamics of the neuron. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that is based on the ability of neurons to store information in their intrinsic properties. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to find favorable conditions. Thus, they are dependent on the delivery of molecules to the interior of the plant for survival. In this work, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules to the interior of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of molecules to the interior of plants. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of molecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for the development of plant-based therapeutics and diagnostics.

The impact of nutrient loading on the health of aquatic ecosystems is a global concern. However, the role of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs is poorly understood. We show that the majority of the daily nutrient loads delivered to Lake Michigan by its tributaries are from a small number of large watersheds. However, the nutrient loads from small watersheds are disproportionately dissolved inorganic, which may increase the likelihood of algal blooms in nearshore areas. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient inputs and suggest that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in lakes should focus on these areas.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to absorb work from its surroundings only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This finding is relevant for the study of the dynamics of complex networks, where the presence of rare combinations of states may be a common feature. It also has implications for the study of the dynamics of chemical networks in the presence of external forcing, such as the one imposed by a magnetic field.

This study provides a detailed description of the mechanisms underlying the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity. This information is important for understanding the mechanisms of the disease, which can help guide the development of new therapies.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of a comprehensive dataset that can be used to reconstruct the history of such events. Here, we present a dataset that includes carbon and uranium isotopes and paleo CO2 levels from a major global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that this event was associated with a major C perturbation and global warming. Our results provide a key dataset that can be used to reconstruct the history of abrupt climate change in the past and to understand the potential for such events in the future.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of deforestation-prone tropical peatlands in the world. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body, and its certification of palm oil plantations is a major tool for reducing deforestation. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation from 9.8 to 6.6% y−1, but that certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of endosomes. The exocyst complex is involved in both processes. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in both plant and human cells. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential drug target for human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex is a major focus of evolutionary research. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that the genetic basis of sex can have a profound effect on the evolution of sexual dimorphism, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple alleles can provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a number of toxic species that are generated by the photoreceptors and their metabolic products. This study shows that the presence of Fe in the retina is important for the photoreceptor-derived toxic species, lipofuscin, and that Fe is important for the degradation of the toxic species. These findings have implications for the development of strategies to protect the retina from the toxic effects of lipofuscin and the degradation products.

Predators are the key drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that this is not the case in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use specialized tentacle structures for prey capture. We show that siphonophore specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional changes in the tentacles, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentacles and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit derived from the amino acid serine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that converts serine to the unit, and have shown that it is a promising target for cancer therapy. We have also identified a metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to therapy. This work provides a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of cancer, and may lead to the development of a new class of targeted cancer therapy.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets has been largely overlooked in the literature. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can reduce vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which can increase vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the agricultural productivity increase over the last century. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
